name: iron-ajax

properties.name: url
properties.description: The URL target of the request.

properties.name: params
properties.description:
An object that contains query parameters to be appended to the
specified `url` when generating a request. If you wish to set the body
content when making a POST request, you should use the `body` property
instead.

properties.name: method
properties.description:
The HTTP method to use such as 'GET', 'POST', 'PUT', or 'DELETE'.
Default is 'GET'.

properties.name: headers
properties.description:
HTTP request headers to send.

Example:

    <iron-ajax
        auto
        url="http://somesite.com"
        headers='{"X-Requested-With": "XMLHttpRequest"}'
        handle-as="json"></iron-ajax>

Note: setting a `Content-Type` header here will override the value
specified by the `contentType` property of this element.

properties.name: contentType
properties.description:
Content type to use when sending data. If the `contentType` property
is set and a `Content-Type` header is specified in the `headers`
property, the `headers` property value will take precedence.

Varies the handling of the `body` param.

properties.name: body
properties.description:
Body content to send with the request, typically used with "POST"
requests.

If body is a string it will be sent unmodified.

If Content-Type is set to a value listed below, then
the body will be encoded accordingly.

   * `content-type="application/json"`
     * body is encoded like `{"foo":"bar baz","x":1}`
   * `content-type="application/x-www-form-urlencoded"`
     * body is encoded like `foo=bar+baz&x=1`

Otherwise the body will be passed to the browser unmodified, and it
will handle any encoding (e.g. for FormData, Blob, ArrayBuffer).

properties.name: sync
properties.description:
Toggle whether XHR is synchronous or asynchronous. Don't change this
to true unless You Know What You Are Doingâ„¢.

properties.name: handleAs
properties.description:
Specifies what data to store in the `response` property, and
to deliver as `event.detail.response` in `response` events.

One of:

   `text`: uses `XHR.responseText`.

   `xml`: uses `XHR.responseXML`.

   `json`: uses `XHR.responseText` parsed as JSON.

   `arraybuffer`: uses `XHR.response`.

   `blob`: uses `XHR.response`.

   `document`: uses `XHR.response`.

properties.name: withCredentials
properties.description: Set the withCredentials flag on the request.

properties.name: timeout
properties.description: Set the timeout flag on the request.

properties.name: auto
properties.description:
If true, automatically performs an Ajax request when either `url` or
`params` changes.

properties.name: verbose
properties.description: If true, error messages will automatically be logged to the console.

properties.name: lastRequest
properties.description: The most recent request made by this iron-ajax element.

properties.name: loading
properties.description: True while lastRequest is in flight.

properties.name: lastResponse
properties.description:
lastRequest's response.

Note that lastResponse and lastError are set when lastRequest finishes,
so if loading is true, then lastResponse and lastError will correspond
to the result of the previous request.

The type of the response is determined by the value of `handleAs` at
the time that the request was generated.

properties.name: lastError
properties.description: lastRequest's error, if any.

properties.name: activeRequests
properties.description:
An Array of all in-flight requests originating from this iron-ajax
element.

properties.name: debounceDuration
properties.description: Length of time in milliseconds to debounce multiple automatically generated requests.

properties.name: jsonPrefix
properties.description:
Prefix to be stripped from a JSON response before parsing it.

In order to prevent an attack using CSRF with Array responses
(http://haacked.com/archive/2008/11/20/anatomy-of-a-subtle-json-vulnerability.aspx/)
many backends will mitigate this by prefixing all JSON response bodies
with a string that would be nonsensical to a JavaScript parser.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.description:
By default, iron-ajax's events do not bubble. Setting this attribute will cause its
request and response events as well as its iron-ajax-request, -response,  and -error
events to bubble to the window object. The vanilla error event never bubbles when
using shadow dom even if this.bubbles is true because a scoped flag is not passed with
it (first link) and because the shadow dom spec did not used to allow certain events,
including events named error, to leak outside of shadow trees (second link).
https://www.w3.org/TR/shadow-dom/#scoped-flag
https://www.w3.org/TR/2015/WD-shadow-dom-20151215/#events-that-are-not-leaked-into-ancestor-trees

properties.name: rejectWithRequest
properties.description:
Changes the completes promise chain from generateRequest to reject with an object
 containing the error message as well as the request.

properties.name: queryString
properties.description:
The query string that should be appended to the `url`, serialized from
the current value of `params`.

properties.name: requestUrl
properties.description:
The `url` with query string (if `params` are specified), suitable for
providing to an `iron-request` instance.

properties.name: requestHeaders
properties.description:
An object that maps header names to header values, first applying the
the value of `Content-Type` and then overlaying the headers specified
in the `headers` property.

methods.name: toRequestOptions
methods.description:
Request options suitable for generating an `iron-request` instance based
on the current state of the `iron-ajax` instance's properties.

methods.name: generateRequest
methods.description: Performs an AJAX request to the specified URL.

description:
The `iron-ajax` element exposes network request functionality.

    <iron-ajax
        auto
        url="https://www.googleapis.com/youtube/v3/search"
        params='{"part":"snippet", "q":"polymer", "key": "YOUTUBE_API_KEY", "type": "video"}'
        handle-as="json"
        on-response="handleResponse"
        debounce-duration="300"></iron-ajax>

With `auto` set to `true`, the element performs a request whenever
its `url`, `params` or `body` properties are changed. Automatically generated
requests will be debounced in the case that multiple attributes are changed
sequentially.

Note: The `params` attribute must be double quoted JSON.

You can trigger a request explicitly by calling `generateRequest` on the
element.
